title: Once Sky High, Abu Dhabi's Prices Tumble to Earth

snippet: Glenavon House, bult in the 1880s for the owner of a paper mill, has been completely renovated.

snippet: So-called specialty drugs for diseases like rheumatoid arthritis have a narrow use and high costs, leaving the most vulnerable patients with huge bills.

snippet: The lawsuit says current and former executives and board members breached their fiduciary duty in their handling of allegations involving a Mexican subsidiary.

snippet: Some say that the best hope for international standards would be their enforcement by the United States.

snippet: Government advisers recommended that the F.D.A. approve the weight-loss drug lorcaserin.

snippet: While state and local governments spend less on higher education, the volume of federally guaranteed loans to students at commercial colleges continues to grow.

snippet: With its banks heavily exposed to Greek debt, the country is nervously watching Greece’s crisis unfold.

snippet: Architect uses courtyards and views to bring the outdoors into his residential designs.

snippet: The fact the stock market is up this month, albeit only a little, should remind us that the cliché “investors hate uncertainty” is nonsense.

snippet: Lockheed Martin will make commercial use of quantum computing, which could solve some business and science problems millions of times faster than can be done today.

title: Hermès Profit Rises, and Not Just in Asia
snippet: The French luxury group said profit jumped 23 percent last year, to about €3.5 billion, and said its operating margin, at 32.1 percent, was the highest since 1993.

title: Global Ticket Sales for Movies Rise 6%
snippet: China, with $2.7 billion in ticket sales last year, passed Japan to become the second-biggest market for films, according to industry statistics.

title: New York Court Upholds Sales Tax for Online Retailers
snippet: The court rejected arguments from Amazon and Overstock that they should be exempt from a state law requiring online retailers to collect sales taxes on purchases made by New York residents.

title: Cyberattacks Seem Meant to Destroy, Not Just Disrupt
snippet: Corporate leaders have long feared hacking in service of fraud or spying, but now a new threat has taken hold: attackers, possibly with state support, who seem bent on destruction.

title: Controls on Capital Come Late to Cyprus
snippet: Cyprus would be better off now had huge amounts of money not flowed into its banks in 2008 and 2009.

title: H.P. Chairman Steps Down as 2 Resign From Board
snippet: The company said Raymond J. Lane was stepping down just two weeks after his narrow re-election.

title: Finding a Rate That’s Fairer Than Libor
snippet: A benchmark based on secured loans makes more sense than the London interbank offered rate.

title: Ex-Bank Officials Named in Cyprus Inquiry
snippet: A report said two senior executives at the Bank of Cyprus might have deleted documents related to the decision to invest in Greek government bonds just before Greece’s bailout in 2010.

title: B.J. Novak, Actor and Writer, Signs Two-Book Deal
snippet: Mr. Novak, a writer for “The Office” and one of the show’s stars, is expected to publish the first book next year.

title: Bitcoin Has Real-World Investors
snippet: The Times’s Nathaniel Popper discusses Bitcoin, the online currency that has attracted a number of investors, including Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss.

title: Twelve, Imprint of Grand Central, Names Publisher
snippet: Deb Futter succeeds Cary Goldstein, who has been at Twelve since its inception seven years ago.

title: Lionsgate Updates Its Animated Logo
snippet: Studios regularly update their logos, but Lionsgate, looking to underscore its growth, adopted a radically different one.

snippet: The announcement, expected Friday, will most likely involve a Lexus line. It would be the first time the Lexus model had been built in America.

title: Judge Rules Against Viacom in Copyright Suit Against YouTube
snippet: Viacom had claimed that the Web video service violated copyright law by showing unauthorized clips of shows like “South Park.’'

title: In Two-Way Charging, Electric Cars Begin to Earn Money From the Grid
snippet: An experiment with two-way chargers allows consumers to power their cars and also send power back to their electric company.

title: ‘The Great Gatsby’ Revival
snippet: A film remake of “The Great Gatsby” is sparking strong new interest in F. Scott Fitzgerald’s novel, 88 years after its first publication.

title: Media Decoder: ‘Duck Dynasty’ Finale Sets Ratings Record for A&E
snippet: The finale was watched by 9.6 million viewers, the show’s biggest audience yet.

title: The Corporate Tax Game
snippet: What appears to be widespread support for an overhaul of the corporate tax system may be a veneer covering deep splits between businesses that get the breaks and those that don’t.

title: British Lobbying Group Condemns a Proposed European Financial Transaction Tax
snippet: London businesses would be hurt the most, said a report.

title: Kurtz Leaves Daily Beast After Blog Post Is Retracted
snippet: The influential media critic was heavily criticized this week for a blog post about the basketball player Jason Collins.

title: Randy Jackson to Leave ‘American Idol’
snippet: His announcement came amid reports that the Fox network has decided to remove all of the show’s on-air judges and its executive producer.

title: NBC Announces 5 New Shows, With Familiar Names Attached
snippet: Among those returning to the network are Sean Hayes of “Will and Grace” and the creator of “Parenthood.” Also, the network will bring back “Parks and Recreation.”

title: Greece Makes Progress in Opening Restricted Professions
snippet: Officials said that the deregulated market offered greater opportunities to the country's jobless even as new figures showed unemployment edging higher.

title: J.&J. Unit Phasing Out All-Metal Hip Devices
snippet: Johnson & Johnson faces a wave of lawsuits from patients who say they were injured when all-metal implants sold by the company failed.

title: New Jersey Hospital Has Highest Billing Rates in the Nation
snippet: The Bayonne Medical Center billed Medicare for common treatments at a rate more than four times the national average, according to a Times analysis of 2011 data.

title: J.C. Penney’s New Plan Is to Reuse Its Old Plans
snippet: The department store chain’s former chief executive, who is now its new chief executive, is reinstating old pricing and promotion policies to lure alienated customers back through its doors.

snippet: The C.E.O. of YouSendIt says leaders must always be clear about where they are taking a company.

title: European Parliament Moves to Limit Scope of Eventual U.S. Trade Deal

title: A Good Manager Must Be More Than a Messenger
snippet: Roman Stanek has started more than five companies and says he has the ability to see where technology is going.

snippet: Officials hailed the deal as a landmark agreement, but environmentalists said it might not be ambitious enough.

snippet: The deal, announced on Wednesday, will pay Fleetwood Mac when the band’s songs are played on the radio and on the Internet.

snippet: One company offers an example of what it means to “go dark,” without the need to file financial information with the S.E.C.

title: Quarrels Continue Over Repository for Nuclear Waste

title: Europe’s Bank Deal Is Seen as Progress With Flaws
snippet: The agreement is intended to reduce the chance that a bank crisis will create a government debt crisis, but risk to weaker countries remains.

title: Warren Mosler, a Deficit Lover With a Following
snippet: From his home in the Virgin Islands, Mr. Mosler is waging a well-financed academic battle against economists who want to cut government spending.

snippet: The film studio will work with Kevin McCollum, a Broadway producer, to create live theater out of movies in its catalog.

snippet: As seen at the sprawling Marché aux Puces, Paris’s most famous flea market, concerns are growing for France’s economic health in the near future.

title: Monte dei Paschi, Venerable Italian Bank, Yields to Change

snippet: In an ad campaign, the network is trying to enlist the help of cable subscribers to push a fee deal through for stations in New York, Los Angeles and Dallas.

snippet: The company blamed the declining personal computer market and disappointing sales of its Surface RT tablet for missing Wall Street’s quarterly forecasts.

snippet: The oil services company will pay the maximum allowable fine and be subject to three years of probation, the Justice Department said.

snippet: Representative Melvin L. Watt, a Democrat from North Carolina, says the measure is an effort to get payment for record companies and artists whose music is played on AM or FM radio.

snippet: Results of a study could indicate that people who are willing to violate one set of social norms are more likely to be willing to violate far more serious ones.

snippet: Tom Rothman, previously the chairman and chief executive of Fox  Filmed Entertainment, will head a venture at Sony that expects to make four films a year.

snippet: The app, which recommends concerts for the hipster crowd, received the investment from some big players in the music industry.

snippet: Opposition to the high-speed railroad has spread to parts of northern England, the region that the project is supposed to help.

snippet: With nine European Union countries about to lift labor restrictions, and with discontent at home, some in Bulgaria are finding it hard to stay.

snippet: The regional government of Andalusia contends $2.46 million in public money was spent illegally to pay for events and gifts to officials.

snippet: Business officials say advocacy groups often demonize companies unfairly and inaccurately, while the groups question why corporations have attacked such fledgling organizations.

snippet: The retailer will award grants for new production processes as it pushes for more American-made products.

snippet: The issue, as the Republicans and their witnesses at the hearing they convened see it, is that the law defines full-time employment as working 30 hours a week, rather than 40.

snippet: One proposal would bring back pensions while a plan by the Obama administration would give younger people a break on market risk.

title: New Google C.F.O. Gets $70 Million Pay Package (and $7,500 to Move)
snippet: Google’s new financial chief will join the search giant in May after a long career at Morgan Stanley.

title: Reading the Fine Print in the Heinz-Kraft Deal
snippet: A look under the hood at everything from the makeup of the board of directors to the payment of a dividend, and not cash, to Kraft shareholders.

title: Citigroup Report Chides Law Firms for Silence on Hackings
snippet: The report said the reluctance of most law firms to publicly discuss breaches and the lack of reporting requirements made it impossible to determine if such attacks were increasing.

title: Feeling Left Out at Lunch
snippet: A writer asks about a supervisor who has lunch with the same group every day; one member of this group received a promotion that the writer had sought.

title: Iran Deal May Be Slow to Affect Oil Sector
snippet: Energy experts said any appreciable impact on an already glutted global oil market was highly doubtful for at least six months and probably more than a year.

title: A Three-Pronged Front to Limit Shareholder Litigation
snippet: Three proposed amendments to corporate law in Delaware have the potential to transform the landscape of shareholder litigation in the United States.

title: Perella Weinberg Poaches Top Telecom Banker From Lazard
snippet: The firm has hired as a partner George H. Young III, known as Woody, the lead banker in many big deals including AT&T’s $49 billion takeover of DirecTV.

title: Amazon to Sell Predictions in Cloud Race Against Google and Microsoft
snippet: Amazon Web Services, the world’s biggest cloud company, is now selling cheap data analysis and prediction. It’s likely to get baked into all kinds of applications, bringing pain to the old guard.

title: Listeria in Sabra Hummus Prompts New Wave of Recalls
snippet: The discovery of the potentially lethal bacterium has been linked to three deaths and five illnesses in Texas and Kansas.

title: David Makol, Known for Pursuit of Insider Trading Cases While at F.B.I., Joins S.E.C.
snippet: Mr. Makol, who helped secure cooperative testimony in cases against the chief of Galleon Group and others, is joining the market-abuse unit at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Vanity Fair Updates Article by NBC Reporter Engel
snippet: The magazine said that Richard Engel now says that he was kidnapped in 2012 by a Sunni militant group, not forces affiliated with the government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, as he originally reported.

title: Is Slack Really Worth $2.8 Billion? A Conversation With Stewart Butterfield
snippet: The corporate messaging start-up Slack raised $160 million at a $2.8 billion valuation. Stewart Butterfield, the company’s chief executive, discusses Silicon Valley’s easy-money moment.

title: Congressional Panels Approve Fast Track for Trade Deal, With Conditions
snippet: The package of bills intended to speed completion of the deal also imposes difficult burdens on its negotiators.

title: Resistance to Verizon FiOS Promotion
snippet: Disney and Fox said they would not run a commercial for FiOS’s new cable package on some of their channels.

title: Kleiner Perkins Seeks Nearly $1 Million From Ellen Pao
snippet: The firm filed for reimbursement of its expenses in a gender discrimination case, but indicated it would accept her dropping the case instead.

title: A Worse-Than-Expected $55 Million First-Quarter Loss for DreamWorks Animation
snippet: Jeffrey Katzenberg, DreamWorks Animation’s chief executive, says this is ‘a transitional year’ for the studio.

title: Sarah Dahlgren, New York Fed’s Top Bank Supervisor, to Leave
snippet: No reason was given for the resignation of Sarah J. Dahlgren, who was promoted in recent years as part the Fed’s efforts to bolster its regulatory efforts.

title: Malta Offers Citizenship and All Its Perks for a Price
snippet: For $1.3 million, a foreigner can obtain a Maltese passport, residency with tax advantages and freedom to move throughout the European Union.

title: Spotify Seeking Video Deals With Media Companies
snippet: The streaming music service hopes to keep users on its site longer, and sell more ads, by offering playlists of short video clips.

title: How Jonathan Steinberg Made Good on a Second Chance
snippet: Despite setbacks that included his father’s failures as well as his own, Jonathan Steinberg now runs one of the fastest-growing fund companies around.

title: Uber Joins the Bidding for Here, Nokia’s Digital Mapping Service
snippet: The battle to buy Here highlights the growing importance of digital mapping services as companies connect their products to the Internet.

title: Blackstone Buys Minority Stake in Hedge Fund Magnetar Capital
snippet: It is the latest deal for the hedge fund arm of Blackstone, which has raised more than $3 billion to buy minority stakes in hedge funds.

title: Changing Course, Russia Will Sell Rubles Instead of Buying
snippet: The move is a result of the strength of the Russian currency, which is up 21 percent this year, and will limit its rise.

title: Rdio Introduces a Cheaper Limited Subscription for Music Streaming
snippet: The new service, Rdio Select, will cost $4 a month, significantly lower than the industry’s $10 standard price.

title: Goldman Sachs Meeting in Bay Area Shows Appetite for Tech
snippet: The investment bank, eager to court technology businesses while a boom is luring billions of investor dollars, held its annual meeting in San Francisco.

title: Hewlett-Packard Reports Drop in Profit and Sales
snippet: The computer and printer company plans to split into two entities later this year in hopes of being more nimble, but investors have reservations.

title: CVS’s Deal for Omnicare May Signal a Slowdown in Pharmacy Mergers
snippet: The increasing concentration in the pharmacy business is already raising antitrust concerns, and the era of frantic mergers may be nearing an end.

title: Breaking Silence, Richard Fuld Speaks on Love, Putin and ‘Rocky’
snippet: In his first public appearance since 2008, Mr. Fuld mused about the economy, the Middle East, love and life, but danced around the downfall of his firm, Lehman Brothers.

title: Madoff Accountant Avoids Prison Term
snippet: David G. Friehling, who worked for the Ponzi scheme mastermind Bernard L. Madoff, was sentenced to a year of home detention and year of supervised release.

title: How Netflix Keeps Finding Itself on the Same Side as Regulators
snippet: The invisible hand of Netflix has been at work influencing policy and proposed mergers in the cable, broadband and media businesses.

title: Petco Takes ‘Full Responsibility’ for Retriever’s Death, but Says Heat Was Not the Cause
snippet: After Colby, the golden retriever, recently died in a drying cage at one of its Virginia locations, the pet supplies company released a statement disclosing findings from an internal investigation.

title: Black Caucus Is Wooed for Trade Pact Votes
snippet: African-American lawmakers are feeling the presidential touch as President Obama reaches out for votes on his trade bill.

title: In Greek Debt Puzzle, the Game Theorists Have It
snippet: In talks with European officials, Yanis Varoufakis, Greece’s finance minister, is playing the kind of game that his friend John Nash Jr., the mathematician, had in mind.

title: Costolo Exit at Twitter Kick-Starts Deal Speculation
snippet: Twitter executives and their advisers took pains to say that Dick Costolo’s departure as C.E.O. was not tied to an external event, but rumors persist.

title: Pie Attack on Rupert Murdoch
snippet: Mr. Murdoch, the chairman and chief executive of News Corporation, was attacked with a shaving cream pie by a protester while testifying before a British Parliament committee in 2011.

title: Shares of Axovant, Alzheimer’s Drug Developer, Surge on Trading Debut
snippet: The company, which bought an unproven Alzheimer’s drug for $5 million, is now valued at nearly $3 billion. The successful debut renews concerns that biotechnology stocks are in bubble territory.

title: Rand Paul and the VAT That Dare Not Speak Its Name
snippet: A closer look at the presidential candidate’s new proposal for what he is calling a business-activity tax.

title: Despite Tensions, U.S. Company Officials Attend Russian Economic Forum
snippet: The White House discouraged participation, but that reportedly didn’t stop 70 American chief executives and officers. And the European turnout was even greater.

title: New Rules Let Companies Sell Stakes to Investors of Modest Means
snippet: Complex and controversial, the regulatory change allows businesses to advertise their offerings online, giving fans a chance to buy shares.

title: Nurse Pleads Guilty to Taking Kickbacks From Drug Maker
snippet: Heather Alfonso of Connecticut accepted $83,000 to prescribe Subsys, a powerful painkiller made by Insys Therapeutics. Prosecutors appear to be looking more closely at the company.

title: Humana Said to Pursue Sale as Supreme Court Ruling Gives Insurers a Lift
snippet: Humana, the smallest of the big five insurers, could reach a deal by next week. Among those in the running are two bigger competitors, Aetna and Cigna.

title: Charter Makes Its Case for 2 Mergers, Telling F.C.C. It’s No Comcast
snippet: Charter wants to buy Time Warner Cable and Bright House. In an F.C.C. filing, it outlined why its ownership would be beneficial, all the while dissociating itself from Comcast’s failed takeover.

title: Employers Have Greater Leeway on Unpaid Internships, Court Rules
snippet: A ruling by federal appeals judges involving the studio Fox Searchlight Pictures could have broad ramifications for the way employers rely on unpaid work.

title: Dollar Tree and Family Dollar Will Sell 330 Stores to Seal Merger Deal
snippet: The sale to the private equity firm Sycamore Partners settles a complaint by the Federal Trade Commission that combining the chains would reduce competition.

title: White House Orders Review of Rules for Genetically Modified Crops
snippet: Critics of biotechnology have long said that the current regulatory system is too lax.

title: Greece Official on Reform Proposal
snippet: Panos Kammenos, the Greek defense minister, told reporters that Greece was on track for a deal with creditors.

title: Why China’s Stock Market Bailout Just Might Work
snippet: Unlike Japan in the 1990s, China has the motivation and the resources that may make government intervention in the markets succeed.

title: Perella Weinberg Hires a Senior Goldman Sachs Executive
snippet: Bruce Mendelsohn, the head of restructuring for the Americas at Goldman Sachs, will join the boutique bank’s corporate bankruptcy advisory practice.

title: Treasury to Examine Online Lending Industry
snippet: The Treasury Department’s effort appears more of an informational exercise, rather than an attempt to establish new rules in the $12 billion industry.

title: G.O.P. Is Quiet About Fed Rate Increases, but Democrats Voice Concerns
snippet: Janet L. Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, testified in front of a Senate committee Thursday and was pressed by politicians concerned that rates will rise too soon.

title: Complications Cloud Possibility of a Movie Based on ‘Watchman’
snippet: Several factors affect the possibility that “Go Set a Watchman” by Harper Lee would be made into a film.

title: Sesac Settles Antitrust Lawsuit Over Royalty Rates
snippet: According to the deal, if Sesac cannot agree with the committee on fees, they will be set by a third party. Sesac must also pay $3.6 million in legal costs.

title: Starbucks Profit Jumps 22%; Chief Cites Increase in Customer Traffic
snippet: The coffee chain reported profits of $626.7 million, and its revenue grew 17.5 percent, to $4.9 billion.

title: Government Pension Cuts Tangled in Patchwork of Legal Rulings
snippet: Steps taken by states and cities to rein in pension plans have resulted in a tide of litigation, with vexing and sometimes contradictory results.

title: A Facebook Project to Beam Data From Drones Is a Step Closer to Flight
snippet: The company said its unmanned aerial vehicle, intended to bring Internet access to remote areas, is ready for tests in the upper atmosphere, most likely in the United States.

title: Wells Fargo to End Some Marketing Ties With Home Builders and Brokers
snippet: The bank said it was ending agreements with firms in the real estate industry, such as home builders, that allowed it to market loans to home buyers.

title: In Microsoft’s Nokia Debacle, a View of an Industry’s Feet of Clay
snippet: The technology business is especially vulnerable to rapid, unforeseen transformation, sometimes leading to the mass extinction of giant companies.

title: Humpty Dumpty Deal-Making
snippet: Should Mondelez be put back together again with Kraft? Or should spinoff VMware absorb its parent EMC? It’s fantasy season for all the Street’s men.

title: King Coal, Long Besieged, Is Deposed by the Market
snippet: In a few short years, market forces have accomplished what environmentalists struggled to do for decades: curtail America’s coal consumption.

title: Facebook Joins the Live-Streaming Crowd With a Service for Celebrities
snippet: Facebook has joined the live-stream scene with a video service that airs clips as they’re happening — but it’s only for famous people.

title: Goldman Expands Retail Banking by Taking On GE Capital’s Deposits
snippet: The Wall Street bank is acquiring $16 billion in customer deposits from GE Capital Bank, which General Electric is shedding to focus on its industrial business.

title: Even in the New Alphabet, Google Keeps Its Capital G
snippet: Google’s name is a protected trademark, and the company has fought to keep it from becoming generic, as brands like thermos, cellophane and others have.

title: NBC Extends Jimmy Fallon’s ‘Tonight Show’ Contract Into 2021
snippet: The network extended its commitment to the popular host just weeks before Stephen Colbert takes over “The Late Show” on CBS.

title: Gay Couples Are Eligible for Social Security Benefits, U.S. Decides
snippet: The Justice Department said the Social Security Administration would apply the Supreme Court’s June ruling declaring marriage a constitutional right retroactively.

title: ‘Female Viagra’ Poses Challenges for Buyer Valeant
snippet: Low efficacy, side effects and regulations all threaten to put a crimp in sales of the newly approved libido drug for women.

title: Kazakhstan’s Currency Plunges
snippet: Financial analysts say the currencies of Kazakhstan’s neighbors in Central Asia will likely fall, as well.

title: Ashley Madison Users Face Threats of Blackmail and Identity Theft
snippet: Scammers and extortionists are combing through stolen data on 30 million to 40 million Ashley Madison users in search of targets.

title: F.D.A. Warns 3 Tobacco Makers About Language Used on Labels
snippet: The F.D.A. issued warnings to the makers of Natural American Spirit, Winston and Nat Sherman cigarettes about their use of “additive-free” or “natural” in marketing.

title: U.S. Open Stars Juggle Preparation With Publicity
snippet: The week leading up to the tennis tournament is a marketing extravaganza for companies represented by elite players.

title: An Ad for the ‘Star Wars’ BB-8 Droid Toy
snippet: With a smartphone as a controller, users can steer the little bot along paths, smash it into walls, feet and chairs, and watch as it angrily lights up if its head comes loose.

snippet: The BB-8, a small, round robot that rolls along at the touch of a smartphone, is one of hundreds of toys related to the next “Star Wars” film.

title: Ellen Pao Ends Legal Battle, Citing Personal Resources
snippet: After losing a high-profile sex discrimination case against her former employer, a venture capital firm, Ms. Pao has decided not to pursue an appeal.

snippet: Accident investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board said they found multiple breaches in the engine of British Airways flight 2276, which had to abort a takeoff in Las Vegas.

title: A Venezuelan in Silicon Valley Finds a Niche in Finance
snippet: Meyer Malka of Ribbit Capital became a rising force in Silicon Valley by betting on financial technology when few others did.

title: Fed Announces Unchanged Interest Rates

snippet: The decision to hold off suggests the Fed wants a little more evidence that the economy is truly on the mend.

title: Terror and Corruption Prosecutor Leaves for Private Sector
snippet: Jason P.W. Halperin, who won all of his 13 cases as an assistant United States attorney in the Southern District of New York, is joining a law firm.

title: Deutsche Bank Picks Goldman Executive as Bank and Insurance Adviser
snippet: Celeste Guth will co-head of the global financial institutions group beside Tadhg Flood.

title: Investors Are Mining for Water, the Next Hot Commodity

snippet: The company’s share prices recovered somewhat this week, but investors remain worried about both global economic trends and management missteps.

snippet: Consumers looking for a new car are facing a conundrum: Do they remain loyal to Volkswagen or look to other brands for clean, high-mileage vehicles?

snippet: The private equity giant has teamed up with Banque Pictet to offer loans to collectors using their art as collateral.

title: Bank of Internet Denies Accusation That It Defied Regulators
snippet: After a 30 percent decline in the bank’s stock, the chief executive fiercely criticized a lawsuit filed by a former employee.

snippet: The longtime leader in dolls is slumping and looking for new ways to be relevant in a digital world.

title: Independent Musicians Find Unexpected Rewards in Streaming
snippet: A growing number of musicians who don’t have lucrative CD sales are exploring the moneymaking potential of streaming.

title: Pandora and Big Labels Settle Suit for $90 Million
snippet: The deal involves recordings made before 1972, which are not covered by federal copyright protection.

title: New Rule Adds a Layer of Protection to Swaps Trades

title: The Narrative Frays for Theranos and Elizabeth Holmes

title: Alphabet Edges Toward Settling the Android or Chrome Question
snippet: The company now known as Alphabet has for years supported two operating systems. But Chrome, the lesser-known of the two, will soon lose one of its few exclusive domains.

title: Thanksgiving Sales, for Big-Box Retailers, Are Not a Choice
snippet: While some stores have announced they’ll stay closed Thanksgiving Day — and REI even on Black Friday — the season is too critical for large retailers not to match their rivals’ hours.

snippet: The pill is expected to be less likely to cause kidney damage or loss of bone density, which have become problems for people with H.I.V. who survive into old age.

title: Oscar Munoz, United’s Chief, to Return in First Quarter
snippet: Appointed in September after the dismissal of Jeff Smisek, Mr. Munoz suffered a heart attack last month, but says he is on the mend.

title: With ESPN Gains, Disney Profit Rose 12 Percent in Fiscal Year
snippet: For its fourth quarter, Disney had a per-share profit of $1.20 a share, a 35 percent increase.

title: At Aeroflot, It’s Patriotism Over Profits as Russia Pressures Industry
snippet: As Russia struggles under sanctions and low oil prices, it is pushing its national airline and others to help support homegrown companies.

title: Gene Amdahl, Pioneer of Mainframe Computing, Dies at 92
snippet: Dr. Amdahl played a crucial role in developing the IBM System/360 series, which influenced computer design for years.

title: Lawmakers Ask for Information About Online Lenders
snippet: Four members of Congress and the Treasury Department are trying to determine whether the small-business lenders should be more tightly regulated.

title: Managing Home Heating Costs Before Winter’s Chill Sets In
snippet: Maintaining heating systems with regular tuneups can translate to significant savings for homeowners, who may be avoiding much costlier repairs.

title: Treasury and I.R.S. Propose Rules to Curb Corporate Relocations for Tax Reasons
snippet: The proposals seek to limit the ability of American companies to move their headquarters to take advantage of other nations’ lower tax rates.

title: Facebook to Make Breaking Up Easier to Do

title: 50 Years Ago, ‘Unsafe at Any Speed’ Shook the Auto World
snippet: Today, even some critics of Ralph Nader’s 1965 book acknowledge its impact on the auto industry and safety.

title: Brazil Hedge Fund Star Looks Elsewhere for His Next Big Bet
snippet: Luis Stuhlberger, whose fund has had a remarkable run in Brazil, has grown increasingly bearish about his country’s economic outlook.

title: A Distinctive Stretch of Britain's Coast Changes Hands
snippet: One of the best-loved landscapes in Britain, a three-mile-long shingle spit in Kent, has been purchased by the owner of a nearby power plant.

title: Starbucks Prospers by Keeping Pace With the Coffee Snobs
snippet: Howard Schultz attributes the chain’s recent dazzling performance to the quality of its customers’ experience, and to a newer push toward the high end.

title: Toyota Asks for Ideas About How to Use an Ultrasmall Vehicle
snippet: At an event in San Francisco, entrepreneurs pitched their ideas for Toyota’s three-wheeled i-Road.

title: Data Storage on DNA Can Keep It Safe for Centuries
snippet: Scientists have shown that DNA molecules can be the basis for a long-term storage system potentially capable of holding all of the world’s digital information in a tiny space.

title: Risk to Aircraft From Drones Being Debated
snippet: A report from Bard College researchers will add to the discussion over the extent and nature of the risk that unmanned aircraft pose in air safety.

title: He Was a JPMorgan Chase Whistle-Blower. Then Came the Blowback.
snippet: Johnny Burris filed complaints with his bosses, and when the bank fired him, he got no chance to defend himself, he says, and then black marks appeared on his record.

title: Atlassian Shares Surge on Trading Debut
snippet: The robust showing brings an upbeat close to what has been a generally dismal year for initial public offerings.

title: F.D.A. Allows Maker of Just Mayo to Keep Product’s Name
snippet: Federal standards require that any product called mayonnaise contain eggs, which Just Mayo does not. Now, the F.D.A. has decided that Hampton Creek can keep the Just Mayo name and its logo, as long as it alters its label.

title: The Junk Bond Rout That Wasn’t
snippet: Some worried that the doomed Third Avenue fund could foreshadow a crisis, but others say it was an outlier that doesn’t signal systemic problems.

title: Navigation Systems Still Show the Way, but Also Make the Route Safer
snippet: Systems include information like the weather, congestion and road curvature, but are also starting to control braking and gear selection without driver input.

title: Security Experts and Officials Diverge on ISIS as Hacking Threat
snippet: Officials wonder aloud if public infrastructure could be digitally disabled, but researchers say ISIS is not nearly so sophisticated, or inclined.

title: A Puerto Rican Utility Makes Progress Toward a Debt Deal
snippet: The involvement of two bond insurers signaled that Prepa had found a way to satisfy its bondholders, who expect to be paid about $177 million on Jan. 1, without having to part with that much cash itself.

title: Pep Boys Accepts Higher Takeover Bid From Bridgestone
snippet: Pep Boys agreed to be bought by Bridgestone for $947 million, with the board of the car-parts chain deeming the latest offer from the tire company better than a competing bid from Carl Icahn.

title: A Roller Coaster Year Ends With U.S. Markets Mostly Down
snippet: A three-year rally was followed by a lackluster performance in 2015 but, given the year’s headwinds, it could have been worse.

title: Microsoft to Notify Users of Government Hackings
snippet: The company joins Google, Facebook and others in disclosing when users of email and other services have probably been targeted by hackers working on behalf of governments.

title: It’s an Unobtrusive Assistant Whispering in Your Ear (Not Little Brother)
snippet: Can OrCam, an Israeli company, avoid the privacy criticism generated by Google Glass?

title: A New Economic Era for China Goes Off the Rails
snippet: After its markets plunged last summer, and weeks after President Xi Jinping announced plans to avoid further disruptions, China again finds itself at the center of economic turmoil.

title: Martin Shkreli Used $45 Million E-Trade Account to Secure Bond
snippet: The account at the online securities firm, disclosed by federal prosecutors, is the first public accounting of how much money the businessman has made.

title: In Puerto Rico’s Debt Crisis, an Absence of Enforcers
snippet: With high unemployment and rising departures by residents, Puerto Rico’s decision to skip $37 million of interest and principal payments is probably only the beginning.

title: In Taiwan, Survivor Mentality Stymies Tech Innovation
snippet: As voters chose a new president over the weekend, a rare point of agreement between Taiwan’s fractious political parties was that the tech industry needs help.

title: Amazon Subsidiary Gains Approval to Ship Ocean Freight
snippet: Amazon’s China subsidiary has received United States approval to ship ocean freight for other companies, in another move by the retailer to build out its logistics operations.

title: Goldman to Pay Up to $5 Billion to Settle Claims of Faulty Mortgages
snippet: Goldman Sachs is among the last big Wall Street banks to settle claims for selling flawed mortgage securities.

title: Jamie Dimon’s Compensation at JPMorgan Chase Rises 35%, to $27 Million
snippet: The bank cut the chief executive’s cash bonus and paid its top executives largely in stock awards tied to the company’s performance.

title: Britax Car Seats Recalled After Handle Breaks
snippet: Britax Child Safety said it is recalling 71,000 infant car seats in the United States, citing one report of the handle breaking and a baby being injured.

title: Freeport-McMoRan Battles the Oil Slump
snippet: Once an aggressive bidder for trophy assets, the company now finds itself in the position of a desperate seller as the price of oil and other commodities falters.

title: Politico Will Lose Its Co-Founder and 4 Others
snippet: Jim VandeHei and Mike Allen will leave the political publication later this year, along with others, shaking up a rapidly expanding organization.

title: Chinese-Made Cars Arrive in U.S. Showrooms
snippet: There were snickers in 2007 when the Chinese said they would soon be making cars for the United States. It wasn’t soon, but the vehicles have begun to arrive.

title: Microsoft Profit and Revenue Fall, but Cloud Computing Grows
snippet: Quarterly results underscored Microsoft’s good and bad trends as software floundered while the cloud business continued to grow.

title: Senator Rob Portman to Oppose Pacific Trade Pact
snippet: The announcement by Mr. Portman, a former trade ambassador to President George W. Bush, illustrates the congressional headwinds facing the 12-nation trade accord.

title: End of the Road May Be Near for Side Mirrors
snippet: Many automakers are demonstrating video systems that replace side mirrors with cameras, but it may take drivers some time to get used to them.

title: Six Degrees of Separation? Facebook Finds a Smaller Number
snippet: Just think of yourself as being that much closer to the actor Kevin Bacon.

title: A.I.G. Will Give Board Seats to 2 Activists Who Want a Breakup
snippet: The agreement ends nearly four months of bitter debate pitting Carl Icahn and John Paulson against A.I.G., which has resisted calls to break apart.

title: Uber Agrees to Settle Class-Action Suit Over Safety Claims

title: Airbnb Purged New York Listings to Create a Rosier Portrait, Report Says
snippet: An independent report says the site “misled the media and the public” by deleting over 1,000 listings to show that its hosts obeyed the city’s rules.

snippet: The bank said in a filing that it awarded Michael L. Corbat, the chief executive, $16.5 million in total compensation last year.

title: Volkswagen Memos Suggest Company Misled U.S. Regulators
snippet: Documents suggesting VW executives knew of elevated diesel emissions in early 2014 could create problems with regulators, car owners and stockholders.

title: A Brassy Concept Car Comes Back From the Dead
snippet: The Exemplar I, a ’60s auto show dream car, used brass and copper trim instead of chrome. Left in a junkyard, it’s now restored.

title: Sorting Out Dodd-Frank’s Treatment of Failed Broker-Dealers
snippet: Dodd-Frank’s Title II provision for the broker-dealers, also known as “orderly liquidation authority,” has always been a bit confusing.

title: Lawmakers Urge Commodities Agency to Keep Plan to Limit Futures Contracts
snippet: Lawmakers criticized a report, by a committee composed largely of representatives from the energy and trading industries, that advised the C.F.T.C. to drop proposed limits.

title: Viacom Chief Must Testify on Sumner Redstone’s Mental State
snippet: A judge ordered Philippe P. Dauman to sit for a deposition in the legal battle over the media mogul’s mental competency.

title: Perseus Books Sells Distribution Unit to Ingram
snippet: The deal comes a few days after Perseus sold its publishing business to the Hachette Book Group.

title: Law Firm’s First Latina Partner, With Boost From N.Y.U. Program
snippet: The AnBryce program aims to give students from disadvantaged backgrounds the financial and networking support needed to succeed in school and beyond.

title: Apple Is Rolling Up Backers in iPhone Privacy Fight Against F.B.I.
snippet: Apple’s legal battle with the government tests the limits of law enforcement agencies’ access to personal data.

title: TransCanada Is Said to Show Interest in Buying Columbia Pipeline
snippet: Stung by the rejection of the Keystone XL pipeline project, TransCanada is said to be seeking a new way into the market.

title: For China Banks, Swapping Stock for Debt Is a Stopgap With Pitfalls
snippet: Using shares to pay overdue loans could help banks temporarily shore up their balance sheets. But it could cause greater difficulties down the road.

title: Apple and U.S. Bitterly Turn Up Volume in iPhone Privacy Fight
snippet: The Justice Department said “no single corporation” — even one as successful as Apple — should be allowed to flout the rule of law.

title: Spotify Reaches Settlement With Publishers in Licensing Dispute
snippet: According to several people involved with the settlement on both sides, Spotify will pay over $20 million to settle the case.

title: Fed Lawyer Who Helped Bail Out, and Regulate, Wall St. Will Retire
snippet: Thomas C. Baxter Jr., who helped devise both Wall Street bailouts and enforcement actions against banks that broke the law, plans to leave the New York Fed in September.

snippet: A more generous loan formula for solo ventures is meant to get more very small businesses into the Paycheck Protection Program. But bigger applicants face a two-week pause.

title: F.C.C. Broadband Plan Includes $50 Monthly Subsidy for Millions
snippet: A proposal released by the acting chairwoman of the commission is an attempt to close the digital divide.

title: Why Top Economists Are Citing a Higher-Than-Reported Jobless Rate
snippet: The official rate stood at 6.3 percent in January, but using an expanded metric, Fed and Treasury officials say it’s closer to 10 percent.

title: Two Americans Tied to Carlos Ghosn’s Escape Are Extradited to Japan
snippet: The father and son face trial on charges that they helped Mr. Ghosn, Nissan’s former chief, flee in a speaker box to Lebanon in 2019.

title: Michaels, bolstered by the pandemic craft boom, is attracting buyout interest from private equity.
snippet: Michaels has seen its business boosted by the pandemic, as people turn to hobbies during stay-at-home orders.

title: Ex-Times Reporter Who Used Racial Slur Publishes a Lengthy Defense
snippet: Donald McNeil, who resigned last month after the publication of an article on his conduct during a student trip, writes that he left the paper after “a series of misunderstandings and blunders.”

title: Oprah, Meghan and Harry Draw 17.1 Million Viewers to CBS
snippet: A two-hour special revived a faded TV genre, the “big-get” prime-time interview that once drew tens of millions for exclusive sit-downs with people like Michael Jackson and Monica Lewinsky.

title: Drive-Throughs That Predict Your Order? Restaurants Are Thinking Fast
snippet: Inspired by pandemic lessons that kept customers in cars, chains are adding more lanes and curbside pickup, improving apps and testing menu boards that use artificial intelligence.

title: Grammys television audience shrinks to a new low.
snippet: Viewership fell 53 percent drop compared with last year’s show, to 8.8 million viewers.

title: After 35 years, Carl Hiaasen says farewell to his Miami Herald column.

snippet: The German carmaker outlined ambitious goals to build battery factories as it ties its fate to electric cars.

title: Investors distance themselves from the photo-sharing app Dispo after controversy.
snippet: Multiple investors said they would donate any profits from their investments to organizations focused on survivors of sexual assault after its co-founder was accused of playing a role in a sexual assault scandal.

title: Biden nominates Lina Khan, a vocal critic of Big Tech, to the F.T.C.
Ellen DeGeneres Loses 1 Million Viewers After Apologies for Toxic Workplace
snippet: “The Ellen DeGeneres Show,” a sturdy daytime hit, has had a steep ratings decline since the host addressed accusations by former staff members that led to firings and an internal investigation.

title: Supreme Court Looks for Narrow Path in Investors’ Suit Against Goldman Sachs
snippet: Both sides agreed that generic statements about firms’ integrity and honesty can sometimes be the basis for securities fraud class-action suits.

title: Corporations, Vocal About Racial Justice, Go Quiet on Voting Rights
snippet: “They are complicit in their silence,” one activist said, as bills that would disproportionately affect Black citizens across the country stir public debate.

title: What We Got Wrong About Uber and Lyft
snippet: How can we believe that technology will help solve big problems if Uber’s great promise didn’t pan out?

title: New proposal would ban most foreclosures until 2022.
snippet: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau proposed rules that would prevent servicers from starting foreclosure proceedings until after Dec. 31 and would make it easier for lenders to offer modified loan terms.

title: Supreme Court Backs Google in Copyright Fight With Oracle
snippet: The 6-to-2 ruling ended a decade-long battle over whether Google had improperly used Java code in its Android operating system.

title: What’s Good About Tech Bubbles
snippet: We’re seeing a mania for wacky tech ideas. But tech bubbles aren’t necessarily the worst thing.

title: Some local reporters were barred from a news conference after Daunte Wright’s death.
snippet: The Star Tribune and Minneapolis Public Radio said some of their journalists were kept out of a briefing on the shooting of Mr. Wright.

title: Archegos Left a Sparse Paper Trail for a $10 Billion Firm
snippet: In its eight-year history, the family office that managed the fortune of Bill Hwang never publicly disclosed any stock ownership. Securities lawyers said that was highly unusual.

title: Some Pubs and Shops Reopen in England, Raising Hopes for Economic Recovery
snippet: The pandemic has left Britain with deep economic wounds, but “Monday is a really positive start.”

title: Exxon Mobil makes a pitch for capturing emissions and a carbon price.
snippet: The oil company wants to create a profit-making business out of the capture of carbon emitted by petrochemical plants and other industries.

title: Tribune signals a preference for a sale to a New York hedge fund.
snippet: After a Swiss billionaire pulled out of a possible deal, the newspaper chain cut off talks, for now, with his partner, the Maryland hotelier Stewart Bainum Jr.

title: JPMorgan draws public ire for financing a breakaway European soccer league.
snippet: The bank’s role has made it one of the targets for criticism. European heads of state, former players and supporter groups of the clubs involved were among those speaking out against the plan.

title: Jeff Bezos’ Rocket Company Challenges NASA Over SpaceX Moon Lander Deal
snippet: The space agency picked Elon Musk’s company over two other bidders to take its astronauts back to the lunar surface.

title: A Surprise Ending for the Oscars’ Inclusive Night
snippet: Six years after #OscarsSoWhite, a diverse roster of artists won awards, though Anthony Hopkins’s win over Chadwick Boseman as best actor surprised many.

title: Still Getting Your Head Around Digital Currency? So Are Central Bankers.
snippet: If you are trying to grasp Bitcoin and understand what China’s digital yuan means, America’s Federal Reserve is right there with you.

title: Apple and Epic Trial Opens With a Tour of the Fortnite ‘Metaverse’
snippet: Epic has accused Apple of unfairly using its App Store’s power to take a cut of the money made in Fortnite, a popular online game.

title: Bill and Melinda Gates Are Divorcing After 27 Years of Marriage
snippet: The announcement raises questions about the fate of their fortune. The couple helped create the Giving Pledge, but much of his Microsoft money has not yet been donated.

title: Jerome Powell strikes a hopeful tone but emphasizes the pandemic’s uneven costs.
snippet: “We will only reach our full potential when everyone can contribute to, and share in, the benefits of prosperity,” the chair of the Federal Reserve said as he highlighted disparities made worse during the pandemic.

title: How the Colonial Pipeline Became a Vital Artery for Fuel
snippet: Reliance on the pipeline has grown as rising domestic production of oil and gas has led to reduced refining capacity in the Northeast.

title: Dozens of state prosecutors tell Facebook to stop its plans for a children’s version of Instagram.
snippet: “Without a doubt, this is a dangerous idea that risks the safety of our children and puts them directly in harm’s way,” Letitia James, New York’s attorney general said in a statement.

title: The Biden administration will begin disbursing $350 billion in state and local aid this month.
snippet: States and cities are being given broad discretion on how they can use the money, which is intended to replace public sector revenue, provide extra pay for essential workers, and invest in sewer, water and broadband.

title: A Titan Ascends in Media World’s Game of Thrones
snippet: Jason Kilar was named chief executive of WarnerMedia just last year, but now he is negotiating his departure after being sidelined by David Zaslav, the longtime leader of Discovery.

snippet: AT&T’s WarnerMedia group is merging with the reality programmer Discovery. What does that mean for your favorite shows?

title: Apple’s Compromises in China: 5 Takeaways
snippet: To stay on the good side of the Chinese authorities, the company has made decisions that contradict its carefully curated image.

title: Apple’s Fortnite Trial Ends With Pointed Questions and a Toast to Popeyes
snippet: A decision over the antitrust suit filed by Epic Games, and the future of the $100 billion market for iPhone apps, is now in the hands of a federal judge.

title: United Airlines will start a ticket lottery for vaccinated loyalty program members.

snippet: The new law is a direct response to Facebook’s and Twitter’s suspensions of former President Donald J. Trump.

title: O.E.C.D. Raises Global Growth Forecast Sharply, Citing Vaccines
snippet: The world economy is expected to expand by 5.8 percent this year, but success depends on beating down variants of the virus, the group said.

title: A New Era Dawns for Harley-Davidson
snippet: The feature-stuffed Pan America is a stark diversion for a company long associated with bulky, expensive cruisers. Early impressions suggest a potential blockbuster.

title: The Internet’s Favorite Catalog of Weird Places Rewrites History
snippet: Atlas Obscura has reviewed how it tells its stories about curious places in light of last year’s shift in how Americans view their past.

title: Apple unveils new privacy features, digital IDs and changes to FaceTime.

title: Journalists at The Atlantic unionize, the latest in a wave of media organizing.

snippet: Some developers are sick of Apple being a dictator. Apple says it’s protecting us. Let’s dissect this.

title: What Data About You Can the Government Get From Big Tech?
snippet: The revelations of a leak investigation started in the Trump administration are a reminder that Big Tech companies often hand over information about their users.

title: Judges Halt Race and Gender Priority for Restaurant Relief Grants

title: Fed’s Williams emphasizes flexibility in the central bank’s inflation goal.
snippet: The New York Fed president panned Wall Street’s efforts to put an equation on the Fed’s average inflation approach.

snippet: After an executive shake-up and conflicting statements about its prospects, the start-up demonstrated prototypes of its pickup.

title: Banks will boost payouts to shareholders after the Fed’s all-clear.
snippet: Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo said they would double their dividends. Other major banks offered more modest increases.

title: A new mortgage rule aims to speed modifications and slow foreclosures.

title: The United Auto Workers name a successor to the departing president.
snippet: The union chose its secretary-treasurer, Ray Curry, for the top job until an election next June.

snippet: Despite sticker prices in the millions, the storied brand chronically lost money. The Croatian firm Rimac will take a controlling interest.

title: Oil Nations Again Fail to Reach Deal as U.A.E. Demands Higher Quota
snippet: Monday’s meeting never got started after attempts to mediate the dispute failed to make progress.

title: A big opening for ‘Black Widow’ gives a taste of how theaters and streaming can coexist.

title: As consumers fret about near-term inflation, the Fed is watching closely.
snippet: Inflation expectations jumped in a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, as central bankers watch for signs that price gains will last.

title: Wall Street Sees Blowout Profits Ahead
snippet: Corporate leaders expect rosy company earnings, starting this week.

title: White House Dispute Exposes Facebook Blind Spot on Misinformation

title: As stablecoins explode in popularity, regulators prepare a response.
snippet: Asset-backed digital currencies have outstripped oversight, but the Treasury Department, the Federal Reserve and other regulators hope to change that.

snippet: Over the past decade, China reorganized its hacking operations, turning into a sophisticated and mature adversary.

title: Inflation Has Arrived, but Washington Isn’t Racing to Limit Price Pops

title: Labor Board Official Backs Union Challenge on Amazon Vote

title: Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates finalize their divorce
snippet: Details of how the couple split their assets were not made public. The couple was married for 27 years.

title: Britain Rethinks Letting China Enter Its Nuclear Power Industry
snippet: Financing and security issues are clouding new power station projects.

title: Electric Cars for Everyone? Not Unless They Get Cheaper.

title: Consumers are on the lookout for higher prices, a Federal Reserve survey shows.

title: The Education Department ends its effort to stop states from suing federal student loan servicers.

snippet: As Jerome H. Powell nears the end of his term as Federal Reserve chair, Ms. Yellen will have a say over whether he should stay on. Many progressive Democrats want him replaced.

snippet: Johnson & Johnson is sending shots from South Africa to other parts of the world. African countries are waiting for most of the doses they’ve ordered.

snippet: A proposal in the South Korean legislature is an early test of how forcefully the Biden administration will defend the companies abroad while trying to trim their power at home.

title: Mayim Bialik will fill in as a ‘Jeopardy!’ guest host.

title: The S.E.C. head is considering banning a key way Robinhood makes money.

snippet: A new natural gas power plant, meant to power the city in an emergency, did not come to the rescue when the storm disabled eight transmission lines.

snippet: The organizing campaign, if successful, could upend the company’s labor model. Employees say chronic understaffing has long caused frustration.

snippet: The network’s chief international correspondent, one of the most visible reporters during the withdrawal of U.S. troops, decided to become a reporter after an epiphany on 9/11.

snippet: The bill would rein in production quotas at warehouses that critics say are excessive and force workers to forgo bathroom breaks.

snippet: Weibo accused one account devoted to a BTS member of illegal fund-raising amid a crackdown on 22 pages.

title: Fox buys TMZ from WarnerMedia, deepening its ties with the gossip brand.

title: Intuit to buy Mailchimp for $12 billion.

snippet: A year after announcing the Bezos Earth Fund, the Amazon founder detailed how some of the money would be spent.

snippet: The deal with ConocoPhillips comes with oil prices high, Permian production strong and Shell under pressure to move faster to cut carbon emissions.

snippet: The automaker and a supplier will spend $11.4 billion on three battery factories and a truck plant, creating 11,000 jobs.

title: Top Fed officials say the labor market needs more time to heal.

title: Users turn to Twitter after Facebook outage. Jokes and venting ensue.

title: A safety agency finds no cause to investigate Tesla battery safety.

snippet: Even as more costly fuel poses political risks for President Biden, oil companies and OPEC are not eager to produce more because they worry prices will drop.

title: Netflix employee who criticized Dave Chappelle’s comedy special is among three suspended.

title: Loans Will Be the Key to Banks’ Future Fortunes
snippet: The big banks are expected to benefit from increased consumer spending when they report earnings this week. Where they go from here will depend greatly on lending to households and businesses.

snippet: Black business owners were more likely to get Paycheck Protection Program loans from online lenders than from banks, according to new research.

title: S.E.C. Describes the GameStop Frenzy, but Not What to Do About It
snippet: A long-anticipated report did not suggest any policy changes in response to the meme stock frenzy that caused some little-regarded shares to soar.

title: Dawn Hudson, the C.E.O. of the Motion Picture Academy, will step down in 2023.
snippet: Under her leadership, the Academy has taken steps to diversify and expand its membership.

title: Apple unveils new MacBook computers and updated AirPods.
snippet: The tech giant rolled back some of the changes it had made to its laptops, getting rid of the unpopular Touch Bar and re-adding ports for an HDMI cable and an SD memory card.

title: Dave Chappelle responds to Netflix controversy with a video clip from his concert.
snippet: Mr. Chappelle’s special has put Netflix at the center of a conversation involving transphobia, free speech and employee activism.

title: Facebook’s profit jumps 17 percent.
snippet: The results in the latest quarter are a sign of the company’s financial strength as it faces a public relations crisis.

title: Amazon workers on Staten Island show they have enough support to hold a union election.
snippet: The outcome could bring a second unionization vote at an Amazon warehouse in less than a year.

title: Rivian edges closer to an I.P.O., seeking a valuation above $50 billion.
snippet: The company updated registration documents with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday.

snippet: The California utility already faces state criminal charges over the blaze this year, the second largest wildfire ever recorded in the state.

title: Regulators Ask Congress to Create New Rules for Cryptocurrencies
snippet: A Treasury Department report says stablecoin issuers should operate like banks to avoid destabilizing runs that could erode financial stability.

title: The Fed warns of social media ‘echo chambers’ that pump up meme stocks.
snippet: A Federal Reserve report found the financial system showed broad signs of resilience, but it suggested so-called meme stocks could pose some risks.

title: Wirecutter workers threaten a walkout during a peak shopping week over contract delays.
snippet: Their union, which is seeking higher salary minimums and guaranteed raises, has been negotiating with The New York Times Company for two years.

title: Randal Quarles, formerly the Fed’s vice chair for supervision, will leave the central bank at the end of December.
snippet: Mr. Quarles’s term as a governor could have stretched until 2032. His departure will give the Biden administration more room to remake the Fed.

title: Google executives tell employees it can compete for Pentagon contracts without violating its principles.
snippet: The company abandoned work on an earlier military program after employees revolted.

title: With Gas Prices High, Calls Grow to Tap Strategic Oil Reserve
snippet: President Biden is under pressure to release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Here’s how it works, and how it might lower prices (modestly, and maybe not for long).

title: Hollywood crew union narrowly ratifies its contracts with studios.
snippet: The margin was perilously narrow, with many International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees members viewing the pact as toothless in terms of preventing long working hours.

title: Elizabeth Holmes Hones Her Defense in Day 2 of Testimony
snippet: Ms. Holmes, the founder of the disgraced blood testing start-up Theranos, pointed blame at others and said her company had worked with drug makers.

title: The Holiday Travel Crush Has Begun. Are the Airlines Up to It?
snippet: Thanksgiving will be the biggest test of the system’s resilience since the pandemic began, with millions more passengers than last year.

title: Kevin Spacey was ordered to pay $31 million to the ‘House of Cards’ studio after sexual harassment allegations.
snippet: A secret arbitrator’s ruling was issued 13 months ago and became public on Monday when lawyers for the studio petitioned a California court to confirm the award.

title: Elizabeth Holmes Says Former Boyfriend Abused Her
snippet: Ms. Holmes, the founder of the failed blood testing start-up Theranos, blamed Ramesh Balwani, the former No. 2 at the company.

title: With Omicron’s Arrival, Stocks Will Again Hang on Headlines
snippet: Markets slumped on Tuesday, and analysts expect a bumpy ride for share prices while experts assess whether existing vaccines will be effective against the new variant.

title: Who Is Parag Agrawal, Twitter’s New C.E.O.?
snippet: A longtime Twitter insider and a confidant of co-founder Jack Dorsey, Mr. Agrawal takes over as the social media company confronts various challenges.

title: Chris Cuomo says he will end his radio show, two days after CNN firing.
snippet: The anchor was dismissed by CNN over the weekend amid an inquiry over help he gave his brother and after an allegation of sexual misconduct, which he denies.

title: Trump’s Media Company Is Investigated Over Financing Deal
snippet: A financing company told investors that it wasn’t in deal talks, weeks after its C.E.O. held a private videoconference about a possible deal with Donald Trump.

title: Microsoft Seizes 42 Websites From a Chinese Hacking Group
snippet: The group was likely using the websites to install malware that helped it gather data from government agencies and other groups, the company said.

title: The Labor Department is investigating Apple’s treatment of employees.
snippet: A former employee said she had accused Apple of suspending her and then firing her in September in retaliation for reporting workplace health concerns at a Sunnyvale, Calif., office.

title: Vox Media and Group Nine, digital media giants, have agreed to merge.
snippet: New York Magazine and PopSugar will soon be under the same banner as the media industry looks for ways to bring in more ad revenue.

title: UBS is told to pay $2 billion for helping rich French clients evade taxes.
snippet: The appeals ruling cut a hefty fine but upheld a lower court’s decision that the Swiss bank had used cloak-and-dagger techniques to evade French law.

title: Fox tightens its vaccine rule, removing a test-out option for N.Y.C. office workers.
snippet: The new policy was in keeping with New York City’s vaccination rule for companies in the city.

title: Rothy’s, the recycled-plastic footwear brand, gets a deal valuing it at $1 billion.
snippet: The Brazilian owner of Havaianas, the maker of flip flops, is taking a 49.9 percent stake in the San Francisco company.

title: Oracle takes a big move toward health with a deal to buy Cerner for $28.3 billion.
snippet: Cerner is No. 2 in the electronic health record business with 25 percent of the market.

title: About 20 Apple stores are now closed as the Omicron variant surges.
snippet: Some of the closures were precautionary; others were closed because not enough healthy employees were available.

title: The 2021 Good Tech Awards
snippet: This year, technology companies stepped up on housing and criminal justice — with a dash of whistle-blowers mixed in.

title: Jurors End Fourth Day of Deliberations in the Elizabeth Holmes Trial
snippet: A jury of eight men and four women deliberated for three days last week with no verdict in the case of the Theranos founder.

title: Democrats Blast Corporate Profits as Inflation Surges
snippet: Politicians are placing more blame on greedy companies as prices stay high. But booming consumer demand is enabling firms to charge more.

title: Apple Becomes First Company to Hit $3 Trillion Market Value
snippet: The iPhone maker’s value tripled since 2018 as its sales continued to soar and it spent hundreds of billions of dollars on its own stock.

title: Facebook suspends Marjorie Taylor Greene’s account for 24 hours.
snippet: Twitter permanently banned her account on Sunday after what the company said was her fifth “strike.”

title: Union wins election at a second Buffalo-area Starbucks.
snippet: A second store could add potency to the economic pressure, such as a work stoppage, that winning a contract often requires.

title: Jesse Watters Is Promoted to an Evening Slot on Fox News
snippet: Mr. Watters, a sardonic conservative with a pro-Trump bent, will take over the 7 p.m. hour.

title: Jerome Powell will tell senators that Fed policymakers see high inflation’s toll.
snippet: Central bankers will act to keep rapid price gains from becoming permanent, Mr. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, will say during a renomination hearing.

title: Airlines warn of chaos if 5G mobile service is deployed this week.
snippet: Thousands of planes could be grounded because the new internet technology interferes with sensors, the industry reiterated in a letter to federal officials.

title: Sales of Electric Vehicles Surpass Diesel in Europe, a First
snippet: The popularity of battery-powered cars is soaring while the overall auto market stagnates, a worldwide trend.

title: A North Sea Auction Produces Big Plans for Scottish Wind Farms
snippet: Oil giants like BP and Shell propose to spend billions on renewable energy, bolstering Scotland’s efforts to move away from an economy based on fossil fuel.

title: What is a stock market correction?
snippet: A sell-off pushed the S&P 500 to correction territory, a threshold that signals investors have turned pessimistic about stocks.

title: Four Attorneys General Claim Google Secretly Tracked People
snippet: Three states and the District of Columbia allege that the tech giant misled consumers by continuing to track those who had changed their privacy settings to prevent data collection.

title: Sarah Palin Tests Positive, Delaying Libel Case Against The Times
snippet: Jed S. Rakoff, the judge in the trial, said it would now begin on Feb. 3, after three positive test results for Ms. Palin.

title: Fed Officials Make It Clear: This Time Is Different
snippet: Central bankers on Monday emphasized that conditions are better than they were the last time they backed off their efforts to prop up the U.S. economy.

title: Rachel Maddow, MSNBC’s No. 1 star, is taking a hiatus.
snippet: The anchor is expected to be off until April, leaving MSNBC with a hole in the coveted 9 p.m. weeknight time slot.

title: The New York Times Buys Wordle
snippet: The word game, released in October, has millions of daily users.

title: Producer of ‘The Matrix Resurrections’ sues Warner Bros. over how the film was released.
snippet: The suit by Village Roadshow claims Warner Bros. rushed the release of the movie to help boost HBO Max subscriptions, a revenue stream Village Roadshow doesn’t share in.

title: Peter Thiel to Exit Meta’s Board to Support Trump-Aligned Candidates
snippet: The tech billionaire, who has been on the board of the company formerly known as Facebook since 2005, is backing numerous politicians in the midterm elections.

title: I.R.S. to End Use of Facial Recognition for Identity Verification
snippet: After a bipartisan backlash, the agency will transition away from using a service from ID.me.

title: BlockFi, a crypto firm, reaches a $100 million settlement for failing to register loan products.
snippet: The threat of S.E.C. scrutiny already had scuttled plans by Coinbase, the largest U.S.-based cryptocurrency exchange, to launch a loan product.

title: Microsoft tells workers to prepare to return to the office.
snippet: Starting Feb. 28, “employees will have 30 days to make adjustments to their routines and adopt the working preferences they’ve agreed upon with their managers.”

title: Texas sues Facebook’s parent, saying it collected facial recognition data without consent.
